Sarai and her husband work in carpentry. They specialize in making coffins. Therefore, Sarai would like a loan in order to buy wood. Both she and her husband work hard. Sarai and her family enjoy good health and her business has a future. For this reason, she hopes to receive assistance.

loans.use: to buy wood for making coffins.

loans.name: Doncellas Group

texts.es:
Carmen es una mujer de 23 años de edad, soltera, tiene 2 hijos de 2 y 8 años, y su negocio es la venta de juguetes y productos de temporada.
Ella es buena madre, cariñosa, sensible, sincera, responsable y trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona ‘plan 3000’ un área caracterizada por el gigantesco crecimiento de su población; mineros relocalizados del occidente del país y etnias como ‘Los Ayoreos’ nativas del lugar, se establecieron. Su siguiente generación, en su mayoría se ocupa del comercio y manufactura. De clima cálido, tropical y húmedo, con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 21-35 grados centígrados.
Carmen es una mujer de tez morena, baja estatura, cabello negro largo, su lengua materna es el Guaraní y habla español por cultura general (la segunda de la derecha, usa pantalón color lila con flores, blusa animal print). Su vida la realiza junto a sus hijos; el mayor estudia en la escuela y el menor ya sabe caminar, viven en una casa alquilada que cuenta con agua potable, electricidad y alcantarillado. Debido a sus metas y futuros logros, formó una banca de personas con negocios como; venta de vajillas, venta de celulares, venta de carne de pollo, venta de flores, servicio de té, taller de costura y venta de productos cosméticos, para solicitar un préstamo y progresar en sus negocios. Su negocio es la venta de productos de temporada. La temporada de navidad se acerca y los productos más vendidos son los juguetes, ella ofrece juguetes de tipo aprendizaje, como; ladrillos para armar, libros de pintar, cubos de letras, rompecabezas, etc. Su negocio es conocido por ser de tipo aprendizaje y cuenta con muchos clientes que año tras año la buscan, porque es la única especializada en ese tipo de juguetes; “me ocupo de vender juguetes para el aprendizaje de todo tipo, libros del cuerpo humano, rompecabezas de letras, juguetes para aprender a lavarse los dientes y otros…” comenta. Su sueño es tener una tienda propia para ya no tener que seguir ambulando. Ella desea realizar la compra de juguetes de tipo aprendizaje por mayor para satisfacer la demanda del mercado por la temporada de navidad.
Es por esos motivos que Carmen solicita un préstamo para la compra de juguetes de tipo aprendizaje para satisfacer la demanda de la época de navidad.
texts.en:
Carmen is a 23-year old woman. She is single and has 2 children, ages 2 and 8 years. Her business is selling toys and seasonal products.

She is a good mother, caring, sensitive, sincere, responsible, and hardworking. She runs her business in the "plan 3000" area, which is characterized by its population explosion. Relocated miners from the western part of the country and ethnic groups native to the area, such as the "Ayoreos," settled there. The following generation mostly engages in commerce and manufacturing. It has a warm, tropical and humid climate, with a daytime temperature that varies between 21 and 35 degrees Celsius.

Carmen is a woman with a darker complexion, short stature, and long black hair. Her mother tongue is Guaraní, and she speaks Spanish for the broader culture. (She is the second from the right, in lilac-colored pants with flowers and an animal print blouse.)

She lives her life with her children. The older one goes to school and the younger one already knows how to walk. They live in a rented house that has potable water, electricity, and a sewage system.

Because of her goals and future benefits, she formed a bank with people who have businesses such as: selling silverware, selling cell phones, selling chicken, selling flowers, tea service, tailoring shop, and selling cosmetics, so that they could apply for a loan and move forward with their businesses.

Her business is selling seasonal products. The Christmas season is approaching and the products that sell the most are toys. She offers educational toys such as: building bricks, coloring books, letter blocks, puzzles, etc. Her business is known for being educational, and she has a lot of customers who look for her year after year, because she is the only one who specializes in these types of toys. "I sell all types of educational toys, books about the human body, alphabet puzzles, toys to learn how to brush teeth, and others," she says.

Her dream is to have her own store so that she doesn't have to sell door to door anymore. She wants to buy the educational toys wholesale in order to satisfy market demand during the Christmas season.

This is why Carmen is applying for a loan to buy educational toys to satisfy the demand during the Christmas season.

loans.use: to buy educational toys in order to satisfy the demand of the Christmas season.

loans.name: Clemente

texts.es:
El señor Clemente de 57  años de edad, vive con su esposa, tiene 02 hijos que dependen de él,  vive en una comunidad de San Lorenzo al sur de Honduras,  tiene casa propia  y se dedica desde hace 22 años  a la venta de abarrotería, embutidos y refrescos.
Don Clemente también vende leche porque se dedica a la ganaría, sus clientes son los amigos, vecinos, personas que a diario llegan a su negocio a comprar sus productos, es un hombre trabajador, que desea salir adelante con su familia y también cultiva maíz para subsistencia y para reventa.
Don Clemente está solicitando el préstamo para la  compra de abarrotería como azúcar, aceite, frijoles, agua, café, harina, huevos, etc. y algunos materiales que necesita para reparar el piso de su casa,  con el apoyo de este préstamo  desea mejorar su calidad de vida, está muy agradecido con Prisma  por apoyar su negocio y su sueño es mejorar su casa.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Noviembre del 2014.
texts.en:
Señor Clemente, 57, has two children who depend on him. He lives in a community of San Lorenzo in the South of Honduras. He has his own house and for the last 22 years he has worked selling groceries, deli meats and soft drinks.

Don Clemente also sells milk because he also raises livestock. His customers are his friends, neighbours, and people who visit his business every day to buy his products. He is a hard-working man who wants to get ahead along with his family. He also grows corn for subsistence and to resell.

Don Clemente is asking for a loan to buy groceries such as sugar, oil, beans, water, coffee, flour, eggs etc. and some materials he needs to repair the floor of his house. With the help of this loan, he would like to improve his quality of life. He is very thankful to Prisma for supporting his business. Clemente’s dream is to improve his house.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - November 2014.

loans.use: to buy sugar, oil, beans and other products for his business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy beer, soap, and cooking oil

loans.name: Marjolyn

texts.en: Marjolyn is juggling a business and responsibility for supervising the renovation of their home. Marjolyn hopes to live comfortably in a house that has good roofing, supported by her loan of PHP 10,000. She hopes to maintain her membership in good standing, with a good repayment record -- a matter that she has given a priority, as a microfinance member of PMPC. This is what she is thankful for, after all her financing needs on her retailing business have been supported by PMPC.

loans.use: to renovate her house.

loans.name: Sabry

texts.en:
Hello lenders! Meet Sabry, a micro entrepreneur who runs a small stall that sells snacks, drinks, mobile phone airtime credits, and serves utility bill payments for his customers. Sabry lives in Serang with three of his family members. Serang is a semi-urban city located about two hours drive from Jakarta. Currently, Sabry is still single but he plans to get married in a few years.

Sabry has been a member of Ruma for three years and he feels glad that he has the opportunity to improve his stall. This time is the second time Sabry is applying for a Kiva loan. The first loan was very helpful for him to process more mobile phone airtime credits and utility bill payment transactions. Sabry is also known as a trustworthy young man in his neighborhood; thus it makes his shop more favorable to go to when people want to buy mobile phone airtime or pay for utility bills. As the business grows, Sabry hopes to get a working capital loan from Kiva to process such transactions. In the photo, Sabry is the one who is standing in front of his small stall. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to use working capital to process more mobile phone credit sales and bill payment transactions.

loans.name: Wilson's Group

texts.en:
In Kwibancha North village in Kuria East, Kenya, Wilson has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Wilson is a friendly member of the community with 4 children. Wilson lives with his family in a house made of mud walls, a dirt floor and an iron roof.

Kwibancha North village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a local water point. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Wilson’s community need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Wilson has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Wilson volunteered to be the promoter because he wants to educate his community that chlorine improves their health so that they are able to work. There are also several other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Peter, Agnes, Susan and Ann.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Wilson’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Mariam's Group

texts.en:
Mariam lives in a home with mud walls, a dirt floor and a grass roof in Nyamanche Kemakoba village in Kuria East, Kenya with her family, which includes 11 children. The community collects their drinking water from a local well because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making the community's inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

The chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. Nyamanche Kemakoba community will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Mariam has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water in order to keep themselves and their families healthy. There are 2 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Samson and Joyce.

Mariam's community needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Mariam believes that the chlorine helps to prevent sickness such as cholera and improves the life of people in her community. 

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Mariam’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Thomas' Group

texts.en:
In Ngukubiganda village in Kuria East, Kenya, Thomas has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Thomas is a friendly member of the community with 8 children. Thomas lives with his family in a house made of mud walls, a dirt floor and an iron roof.

Ngukubiganda village does not have a piped water supply; rather, the community collects their water from Nyamukumana well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Thomas’ community needs a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Thomas has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Thomas volunteered to be the promoter because he believes chlorine kills bacteria and he says chlorine helps to prevent diarrhea and cholera. There are also 2 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Veronica and Rebecca.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Thomas’ community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Esther's Group

texts.en:
Esther is 40 years old, has 6 children and lives in Kemakoba in Kuria East, Kenya. The community of Kemakoba does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that people may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Esther works as a peasant farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Esther and 4 other promoters in her community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Esther will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Esther wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser will prevent waterborne diseases caused by drinking contaminated water.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Esther’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Samwel's Group

texts.en:
In Gaitwa village in Kuria East, Kenya, Samwel has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Samwel is a friendly member of the community with 6 children. Samwel lives with his family in a house made of mud walls, a dirt floor and an iron roof.

Gaitwa village does not have a piped water supply. Instead, the community collects their water from a well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Samwel’s community needs a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Samwel has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Samwel volunteered to be the promoter because he believes the chlorine that kills bacteria will help to prevent water-borne diseases, ultimately improving their health. There are also 3 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Peter, Jackson, and Matinde.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Samwel’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Vincent's Group

texts.en:
Vincent is 55 years old, has 8 children and lives in Girigiri A village in Kuria East, Kenya. Vincent works as a subsistence farmer to earn a living. His community does not have access to clean water. The water used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases like cholera and typhoid. Vincent is a friendly member of the community and has been elected promoter by his community to help them access safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Vincent represents his community on Kiva’s website and educates the community on how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using the chlorine dispenser. Vincent and 3 other promoters (Leose, Agnes and Mary) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Vincent wants to be a promoter because he believes that the chlorine dispenser will help to alleviate water-borne diseases and improve their lives.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Vincent’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Veronica's Group

texts.en:
Veronica is 34 years old, has 9 children and lives in Kagundo village in Kuria East, Kenya. Kagundo village does not have a piped water supply. Instead, the community collects their water from a local water spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Veronica, her family, and other members of the community may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Veronica works as a business owner, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Veronica and 4 other promoters in her community, including Daniel, Hagai, Joseph and Ann, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Veronica will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Veronica wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser will help in making their water safe, thus preventing water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Veronica’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Lydia's Group

texts.en:
Lydia has 4 children, is 30 years old and lives in Nyametembe A village Kuria East, Kenya. Lydia works as a commercial farmer to earn a living. Lydia's community does not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from a spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If the community had a way to treat their drinking water, there could be fewer cases of water-borne diseases, keeping members of the community in good health.

This is why Lydia is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of her community. Lydia was elected to represent her community as a volunteer promoter. She is not only representing her community on Kiva, but also volunteers her time to educate her community on the importance of safe water and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Lydia wants to be a promoter because she wants to alleviate water-borne disease within her community.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Lydia’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary lives in a home with mud walls, a dirt floor and an iron roof in Bitorogwe village in Kuria East, Kenya with her family which includes 1 child. The community of Bitorogwe collects their drinking water from Geitango well because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making the community's inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. Bitorogwe community will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Mary has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water to keep themselves and their families healthy. There are 2 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Pauline and Joanes.

Bitorogwe community needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Mary believes that the chlorine kills bacteria in water making it safe to drink by preventing water borne diseases, thus improving health for children and community in her community.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Mary’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Paul's Group

texts.en:
Paul is a 30 year old man who has 4 children and lives in Komomange, a village in Kuria East, Kenya. Paul works as a subsistence farmer for a living. Paul's community does not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from a local water spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If the community had a way to treat their drinking water, there could be fewer cases of water-borne diseases, keeping members of the community at school and work.

This is why Paul is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of his community. Paul was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. As a health promoter, he volunteers his time to educate the people of his community on the importance of safe water and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Paul wants to be a promoter because he envisions a community free from water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Paul's community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: James' Group

texts.en:
James lives in a home with mud walls, a dirt floor and an iron roof in Kegonche B village in Kuria East, Kenya with his family which includes 6 children. The community collects their drinking water from a local well because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases often making the community's inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. James' community will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. James has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are 3 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: John, Agnes and Daniel.

James' community needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. James believes that the chlorine kills bacteria in water making it safe to drink and preventing water borne-diseases, thus improving the health of children and community members.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that James' community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

texts.en:
Jackson is 30 years old, has 8 children, and lives in Kwinyunyi village Kuria East, Kenya. Jackson works as a peasant farmer to earn a living. Jackson's community does not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from a local water spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Kwinyunyi community had a way to treat their drinking water, there could be fewer cases of water-borne diseases, thus keeping Kwinyunyi community at school and work.

This is why Jackson is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of his community. Jackson was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. He is not only representing his community on Kiva, but also volunteers his time to educate the people of his community on the importance of safe water and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Jackson wants to be a promoter to alleviate water-borne diseases within his community.

Ugu village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. 

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Mildred’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Caroline's Group

texts.en:
Caroline is 38 years old, has five children, and lives in Miranga village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Her community of Miranga village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Caroline is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Caroline represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using the chlorine dispenser. Caroline and two other promoters in her community, including Ezekiel and Eusemiah, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Caroline wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser will prevent water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Caroline’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: John's Group

texts.en:
John is 59 years old, has ten children, and lives in Minya A village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Minya A village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Minya borehole. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that John and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

John works as a subsistence farmer, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. John and other promoters in his community, James and Carolyne need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. John will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. John wants to be a promoter because he believes that the chlorine will reduce water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that John’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Saviour School

texts.en:
Greetings from Uganda! This is Alex. He is the Head teacher of Saviour Junior School, a mixed school in the Peri-Urban area of Bulenga in Wakiso with 200 students. Saviour Junior School has requested a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a UV water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students. The schools do not currently have access to consistent clean drinking water and therefore has to spend a considerable portion of its budget on firewood, which is used to boil water for the children. Installing a water filtration system will therefore save the school money in the long-term as the cost of firewood will be reduced. The loan will enable the school to purchase a UV water treatment system with a 450 litre tank, which will be big enough to store clean drinking water for the students every day. 

Saviour Junior School will repay their loan from their school fees, which they collect each term. Alex ultimately hopes that having access to safe drinking water will improve his students concentration and attendance by reducing the number of children that fall sick from water-borne diseases as well as increase the number of students coming to the school.

loans.use: To purchase a water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: David's Group

texts.en:
David is 30 years old, has 4 children, and lives in Magina Central village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Magina Central village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Kadan borehole. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that David and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

David works as a school teacher, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. David and three other promoters in his community, Christopher, Margaret, and Everline, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. David will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. David wants to be a promoter because he believes that the dispenser will provide safe water to the community.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that David’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Brenda's Group

texts.en:
Brenda is 19 years old, has 1 child, and lives in Kamlungo B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Brenda works as a peasant farmer for a living. Kamlungo B village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Brenda is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Brenda represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser. Brenda and 2 other promoters in her community, Risper and Lucy, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Brenda wants to be a promoter because she believes that by using safe water, the community will have good health.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Brenda’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Juana

texts.es: Juana es casada, tiene 3 hijos y vive en El Alto en una casa de adobe que es de su propiedad, la casa solo tiene luz y agua Juana se dedica a la elaboracion de ropa deportiva (pantalones, chaquetas) y quiere un credito para comprar tela puesto que esta temporada tiene la oportunidad de mejorar sus ingresos El esposo de Juana es chofer de minibus, pero lo que gana la pareja no alcanza para financiar el emprendimiento de Juana y cubrir los gastos de los hijos, por eso ella quiere su colaboracion Al menos Juana y su familia gozan de buena salud por lo que esperan recibir su ayud a
texts.en:
Juana is married and has three children. She lives in El Alto in an adobe house that is situated on her own property. The house only receives electricity and running water.

Juana produces sportswear (pants and jackets). She wants a loan in order to buy fabric since she has an opportunity this season to improve her earnings. Juana’s husband is a minibus driver, but the two of them do not earn enough to finance her business and cover their children’s expenses. For this reason, she wants to collaborate with Kiva lenders. Juana and her family enjoy fairly good health, so she awaits to receive assistance.

loans.use: to buy fabric for making sportswear.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy chickens, chicken feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Tres Marias Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “TRES MARIAS”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Felicia ella es soltera y tiene 55 años y tiene 1 hijo; La socia trabaja en su negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azucar, leche y galletas, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 5 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar arroz, azucar, leche y galletas.
Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de libreria, negocio de venta de verduras, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de restaurant.



La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
These members belong to the Communal Bank “Tres Marias” which is located in the District of Cusco in Cusco Province, Department of Cusco.

Sra. Felicia is one of the members. She is 55 years old, single, and has one child. Felicia works at her grocery business where she sell basic necessity products such as rice, sugar, milk, and cookies. She works from 8:00 A.M. to 7:00 P.M. Felicia has five years of experience in this business and is doing very well. Her dream is to expand her grocery store. She is requesting a loan in order to buy rice, sugar, milk, and cookies.

The other members engage in businesses such as managing a bookstore, selling vegetables, operating a grocery store, and managing a restaurant.

Felicia is grateful to those who have helped to fulfill her dream in this manner. Therefore, she promises to complete her payments according to the established terms.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, milk, and cookies.

loans.name: Rwebijoka Muhumuza Group

texts.en:
Francis is a member of Rwebijoka Muhumuza Group where each member guarantees the other to get a loan since they cannot pledge security. The group lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. 

Francis is married with 6 children, and he is engaged in retail business but also does some farming for extra income. He faces the challenges of inadequate capital and the high cost of rent. However, he hopes to raise a healthy family. 

Francis requires a loan to buy beans and paraffin for resale in his retail business.

loans.use: to buy beans and paraffin for resale.

loans.name: Maria Cristina

texts.es:
María, tiene resultados satisfactorios con la inversión del préstamo anterior, cuenta que la tienda es más rentable y a inicio la crianza de pollos para luego venderlos, tiene estabilidad económica con la que ha cambiado las circunstancias familiares y cancelado la deuda adquirida.
En está ocasión invertirá el préstamo que solicita en la compra de alimento y vitaminas para pollos, así fortalecerá sus actividades económicas y seguirá atendiendo las demandas de sus clientes.
texts.en:
María has had satisfactory results with the investment of her previous loan. She says that the shop is more profitable with her starting to raise chickens to sell them on. She has economic stability with which she has changed her family's circumstances and repaid the acquired debt.

On this occasion she will invest the loan that she is asking for into buying feed and vitamins for the chickens, as this will strengthen her business and allow her to continue meeting her customers demands.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her chickens.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy corn, chickens, pork, tomatoes, oil etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to invest in a bicycle, pan dulce [sweet bread], and French bread

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to maintain her pineapple crops.

loans.name: Hector

texts.en:
Hector established Café La Esperanza in July 2010. Cafe la Esperanza will focus on the sale of organic-certified coffee from Oaxaca to the United States and Europe.  Hector is a very driven businessman; he has many years of experience in the hotel and hospitality industry, as well as the restaurant industry and the banking industry. 

He got involved in the import / export of fair trade coffee in 2007. Once he got started in the coffee business, he knew that this was his calling. He fell in love with the product and has spent many years learning about the coffee industry and the certifications and regulations that he needed to be successful in the business. 

Hector’s goal is to sell his coffee all over the world and to help create employment in Oaxaca. He said there are many people there looking for work and he wants to help them support their families and get out of poverty. 

Hector will use his Kiva loan to purchase additional equipment (computer & printer) needed to make his business efficient.

loans.use: to purchase additional equipment (computer & printer) needed to make his business efficient.

loans.name: Maria Yolanda

texts.es:
La señora María Yolanda de 44  años de edad vive con su esposo y sus 05 hijos en su casa de habitación ubicada en San Lorenzo al sur de Honduras,  se dedica desde hace ya varios años al negocio de elaboración y venta de tortillas. 
Doña María sus clientes son personas que llegan a su casa a comprar las tortillas para el almuerzo y cena, es una mujer trabajadora que desea mejorar su casa. 
Doña María está solicitando el préstamo para la compra de maíz, leña y cal que son la materia prima que necesita para elaborar las tortillas, también necesita  comprar materiales de construcción porque necesita hacer una pila y un baño, con los demás créditos a mejorado su casa está muy contenta de seguir con Prisma.
 Su sueño es mejorar su casa.

  San Lorenzo, Honduras - Noviembre del 2014.
texts.en:
Señora María Yolanda, 44, lives with her husband and five children in her house located in San Lorenzo, in the south of Honduras. For several years she has worked making and selling tortillas. Her customers are private individuals who come to her house to buy her tortillas for lunch and dinner. She is a hard-working woman who wants to improve her house.

Doña María is asking for this loan in order to buy corn, firewood and lime which are the primary materials she needs to make her tortillas. She also needs to purchase construction materials because she needs to build a sink and bath. With the other loans she has improved her house and she is very happy to continue working with Prisma.

Her dream is to improve her home.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - November 2014.

loans.use: to buy corn, firewood and lime for her business.

loans.name: Deysi Carolina

texts.es:
La señora Deysi de 25  años de edad vive con su esposo y su hija en su casa de habitación ubicada en San Lorenzo al sur de Honduras  se dedica desde hace dos años al negocio de venta de abarrotería como ser arroz, frijoles, maíz, frescos, su venta es con sus vecinos y amigos que a diario la visitan para obtener sus productos.
Doña Deysi tiene bien surtido su negocio, es una mujer trabajadora con deseos de salir adelante.
Doña Deysi solicita el préstamo para la compra de frescos, arroz, azúcar, harina, huevos, frijoles, leche, etc.  Con el apoyo de este préstamo pretende mejorar sus ingresos es un cliente nuevo y su sueño es mejorar su negocio.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Noviembre del 2014.
texts.en:
Deysi is 25, lives with her husband and daughter in their house located in San Lorenzo in the south of Honduras.  She has worked for two years in the business of selling groceries such as rice, beans, corn, soda, she sells to neighbors and friends that visit every day to buy her products.
Deysi has a well stocked business, she is a hardworking woman with dreams to get ahead.
Deysi requests a loan to buy pop, rice, sugar, flour, eggs, beans, milk, etc.  With the support from this loan she homes to improve her income, she is a new entrepreneur and her dream is to improve her business.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - November 2014.

loans.use: to buy pop, rice, sugar, flour, eggs, beans, milk, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy construction materials.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy chicken, meat, potatoes, yuca, disposable plates, sodas and water for her business.

loans.name: Digna Alejandra

texts.es:
La señora  Digna de 24 años de edad es casada, tiene un hijo  que depende de ella, vive  en una comunidad de San Lorenzo, al sur de Honduras, vive en casa de un familiar y se dedica desde hace 2 años al negocio de elaboración y venta de tortillas, sus clientes le prefieren por su amabilidad y buen servicio ya que atiende a sus clientes desde las seis de la mañana hasta las siete de la noche. 
Doña Digna es una mujer trabajadora y muy sufrida y su deseo es sacar adelante a su familia y su negocio, está solicitando el préstamo para la compra de materia prima como es  la leña, maíz, cal y mejorar un poco su taller.  Con el apoyo del préstamo se preparara para la época de navidad donde hay bastante demanda en donde se vende bastante la tortilla, está muy contenta de solicitar su primer crédito con Prisma. Su sueño es tener su propia casa.

 San Lorenzo, Honduras - Noviembre del 2014.
texts.en:
Digna is 24 years old, married, and has one dependent son. She lives in San Lorenzo in southern Honduras. She lives in a family member's home and for 2 years has had a business making and selling tortillas. Her customers prefer her for her friendliness and good service that she provides to her customers from 6 AM until 7 PM. Digna is a hard-working, uncomplaining woman and her desire is to help her family and business get ahead.

She is seeking a loan to buy items such as wood, corn, and lime for her business and improve a little her shop. With the help of the loan she will prepare for the Christmas season where there is quite a bit of demand and she sells a lot of tortillas. She is very content to seek her first loan from Prisma. Her dream is to have her own home.
San Lorenzo, Honduras - November 2014.

loans.use: to buy wood, corn, and lime for her business.

loans.name: Martin

texts.es:
Al trabajar la tierra bajo un sol agotador sin embargo dispuesto a sudar todo el tiempo para brindarle un mejor futuro a sus hijos. Martín de 43 años de edad casado, el motivo por el cual el está impulsado en realizar otro préstamo es para una nueva inversión en cultivo de cebollas.

Antes los préstamos eran con otras instituciones, pero no contaban con los beneficios que nos da ADICLA como lo es la forma de pago, intereses mensuales y el capital al vencimiento pus son beneficios que nos ayudan a soñar en un futuro mejor para nuestros futuros hijos.

El uso respectivo que dará al segundo crédito es para la compra de semillas de cebollas y abonos orgánicos para poder empezar a cultivar más productos para luego venderlas en el mercado de su comunidad y así obtener una ganancias para el sustento de su familia y para que tengan las condiciones de vida adecuada. 

El cambio que realiza un crédito es principalmente asegurar  la cosecha con los insumos y el manejo en general de las cosechas agrícolas, para que las personas obtengan productos de la mejora calidad y es lo que a ocurrido con Martín que por medio de los prestamos que se les a concedido el a podido obtener mejores cosechas.

Una de las metas de el es la construcción de casas para sus hijos para una condición de vida adecuada y estudios para sus hijos para que se conviertan en profesionales en la vida y seguir cosechando las tierras fértiles de su comunidad.
texts.en:
Martín is 43 years old and married. He works the land under the grueling son and is willing to sweat all the time so that he can provide a better future for his children. The reason why he is requesting another loan is to that he can invest in a new crop of onions.

Martín previously had loans with other institutions, but they did not offer the benefits that ADICLA provides such as payment options, monthly interest, and principal due on maturity. These benefits help him to dream a better future for his children.

His second loan will be used to buy onion seeds and organic fertilizers so that he can begin cultivating more products. He will be able to sell them at the market in his community so that he can generate income for sustaining his family and provide them with adequate living conditions.

The change that will result from this loan is that he will be able to secure his harvest by acquiring supplies and providing general maintenance to his crops. People who purchase his products will receive the best quality. This is what happened with the previous loans that Martín was issued since he was able to obtain better harvests.

One of his goals is to build houses for his children so that they can provide adequate living conditions and an education for their children. This will help them to become professionals in life and to continue reaping the benefits of the fertile land in their community.

loans.use: to buy onion seeds and organic fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to make repairs to the house where she plans to move.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cement, sand, brick, and gravel to improve the conditions of the bathroom.

loans.name: Maria Orbelina

texts.es:
María, está solicitando un nuevo crédito para comprar granos básicos, verduras, condimentos, carnes, platos, cucharas, etc., equipara el inventario de su negocio para continuar con la venta de comida y pupusas, espera recuperar la inversión con mejores ganancias que serán de utilidad para cubrir sus compromisos.
El impacto que ha tenido el préstamo anterior en el negocio de María es positivo, pues su negocio está ofreciendo mejor variedad de comida, tiene más clientes satisfechos, su nueva situación económica le permite reducir su nivel de deudas, mantener una fuente de empleo y cuidar de su familia.
texts.en: María is seeking a new loan to buy basic grains, vegetables, condiments, meat, plates, spoons, etc to equip the inventory of her business in order to continue selling food and pupusas (a traditional food item). She hopes to recover the investment with better profits that will be used to cover her debts. The impact the previous loan had on Maria is positive, as her business is offering a greater variety of food, she has more satisfied customers, her new economic situation enables her to reduce her level of debt, maintain a source of employment and take care of her family.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, vegetables, condiments, meat, plates, spoons, etc to equip the inventory of her business in order to continue selling food.

loans.name: Ana Daysi

texts.es:
Ana, aprovechara la época de verano para hacer mejoras en local de su negocio, invertirá en materiales de construcción y pago de mano de obra, así tendrá un lugar más atractivo para sus clientes, espera que sus ventas aumenten y seguir teniendo estabilidad en sus ingresos.
La ayuda que Kiva le brinda con préstamos le ha evitado hacer préstamos con otras personas, le dio la facilidad de tener materia prima para la venta de tortillas y las circunstancias familiares son más dignas.
texts.en: Ana will take advantage of the summer to make improvements on her business's locale. She will buy construction materials and pay for labor, in this way she will have a more attractive location for her customers. She hopes that her sales increase and will continue having stable income. The help Kiva gives with loans has helped her avoid taking loans from other individuals, giving her the ability to have the materials to sell tortillas and family living circumstances are more dignified.

loans.use: to buy construction materials and pay for labor, in this way she will have a more attractive location for her customers.

loans.name: Chara

texts.en:
Hello lenders! Meet Chara, a micro-entrepreneur who sells mobile phone airtime credits and serves utility bill payments for his customers. Chara lives in Serang, with three of his family members. Serang is a semi-urban city, located about two hours' drive from Jakarta. Chara is happily married and he and his wife have been blessed with two children.

Chara joined PT Rekan Usaha Mikro Anda (Ruma) about one year ago and he feels glad that he has the opportunity to improve his business. 

This is the second time Chara has applied for a Kiva loan. The first loan was very helpful to him in processing more mobile phone airtime credits and utility bill payment transactions. Chara has the advantage of selling such products because he is a hard-working person in his neighborhood, thus it makes his shop more favorable to go to when people want to buy mobile phone airtime or pay for utility bills. As the business grows, Chara hopes to get a working capital loan from Kiva to process such transactions.  

In the future, Chara plans to improve the new product he serves, which is an ‘e-commerce’ for low-income communities – a new business model from Ruma that is aimed at helping people get access to good quality products with better prices. The products range from fashion products, to housewares and kitchenwares, to gadgets and school supplies. 

To buy an item, people only have to pick things they want to buy from the product list in the catalog. After that, they can go to Chara or any other certified Ruma agents near their houses to make order and payment. The product will be delivered right to the customer’s door.

Chara thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to process more mobile phone credit sales and bill payment transactions.

loans.name: Maa Singhbahini Shg Group

texts.en:
Sobhagini is a 29-year-old, divorced woman living with her parents and three children in a small village of Sambalpur district of Odisha state. Sobhagini is the one who is standing with her hand raised in the group picture. Their group is called Maa Singhbahini Self Help Group.

All the members are involved in the business of growing vegetables. They have been in the business for the past three years. They grow different types of vegetables, some of which is sold to vendors and rest are sold to the customers directly. 

Sobhagini sells the vegetables to many other customers in the nearby market. The group is therefore requesting for a loan. Sobhagini’s share of the loan will be used to buy seeds and fertilizers for her vegetable farmland.

Sobhagini will buy school uniforms for her children and prepare better food for the family with the increased income from this loan. She hopes to keep supporting her family to have regular food to eat, to buy educational materials for her three children and to repay this loan.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers for her vegetable farmland.

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
A father of five, Jose and his entire family work seven days a week at their property in Vista, CA, which houses several greenhouses. They grow a variety of plants, including herbs, succulents, vegetables, decorative plants, hanging plants and flower arrangements. He sells his beautiful plants at five farmers’ markets in the San Diego area. 

Jose moved to San Diego from Chicago with his family for more opportunities. He wanted to be somewhere so he could grow his plants and succulents all-year-round and share his passion for the environment with others. He said that starting a business in a new area was difficult, but it was his love for his family that kept him going. 

Jose’s goal for the business is to have people from all over the world to enjoy his plants. He eventually wants to set up a distribution system, so that people can buy his plants outside of San Diego. 

He is going to use his Kiva loan to expand to more farmers’ markets within the San Diego area and upgrade some of the equipment in his greenhouses. 

Jose is so grateful for the generous Kiva lenders and he wants them to know that this loan was a blessing to him and it is helping him live his dreams and provide for his family.

loans.use: to expand to more farmers’ markets within the San Diego area and upgrade some of the equipment in his greenhouses.

loans.name: Feliciano

texts.es:
El señor Feliciano de 47 años de edad vive con su esposa no tiene hijos que dependan de él, vive en su casa de habitación, en una comunidad San Lorenzo al sur de Honduras se dedica desde hace 4 años al negocio de venta de verduras y frutas, también vende leña seca para los negocios de golosinas y tortillas.
Don Feliciano es un hombre emprendedor con deseos de salir adelante, está solicitando el préstamo para compra de frutas como manzanas, uvas, bananos, piña, papas, yuca, plátanos, etc. Para tener mas producto para la venta en esta temporada de navidad, desea poder salir adelante con su negocio y su sueño es crecer con su negocio y mejorar su calidad de vida y también comprarse un carro para vender sus verduras.

San Lorenzo, Honduras – Noviembre del 2014.
texts.en:
Feliciano is 47 years old and lives with his wife. He doesn't have any dependent children. He lives in his own home in San Lorenzo in southern Honduras. For 4 years he has had a business selling fruit and vegetables. He also sells dry firewood for candy and tortilla businesses. Feliciano is an enterprising man with the desire to be successful. He is seeking a loan to buy apples, grapes, bananas, pineapple, potatoes, yucca, plantains, etc.in order to have more products to sell during this Christmas season. He wishes to be successful with his business and his dream is grow the business and improve his quality of life and also buy himself a cart in order to sell his vegetables.

San Lorenzo, Honduras – November 2014.

loans.use: to buy apples, grapes, bananas, pineapple, potatoes, yucca, plantains, etc. for his business.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene works hard to support her family. She is married and has a buy-and-sell sand and gravel business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 2 years now.

Arlene has requested a 10,000 PHP loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation in order to buy additional tons of sand and gravel to sell.

Arlene would like to be able to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional tons of sand and gravel to sell.

loans.name: Toton

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Meet Toton, a micro-entrepreneur who lives in Serang, a semi-urban city located about 2 hours from Jakarta, Indonesia. 

Toton manages a small shop where he sells snacks, drinks, mobile phone airtime credits, and processes utility bill payments for his customers. He is still single, and he lives with 6 family members in his family's home. 

18 months ago, Toton decided to join Ruma because he wanted to improve his shop. This is his second loan from Ruma, and he is now applying for a working capital loan. His business is running very well; however, he requires capital in order to process more transactions, especially on the weekends. 

In the future, Toton plans to add one more product from Ruma, which is ‘e-commerce’ for low income communities – a new business model from Ruma that is aimed to help customers access good quality products at better prices.

loans.use: to process more mobile phone credit sales and bill payment transactions.

loans.name: Club De La Amistad Group

texts.es: Liliana de 34 años de edad es separada y tiene 02 hijos dependientes. La Alcancía Comunal “Club De La Amistad” conformada por 09 socios responsables y dinámicos. Liliana se dedica a la venta de prendas de baño y vestir. Hace más de 06 años que se dedica a dicho negocio de forma ambulatorio. Su mayor anhelo es contar con su propio local de venta para así dar un mejor servicio a sus clientes. Solicitó el  crédito para la compra de toallas, shorts, y bivirís. El grupo “Club De La Amistad” agradece a los inversionistas Kiva por el crédito brindado. Liliana se encuentra en la parte posterior es la primera del lado derecho y viste polo negro.
texts.en:
Liliana is 34 years old, separated, and has two dependent children. The communal bank "Club De La Amistad" ["Friendship Club"] is made up of nine responsible and dynamic members. 

Liliana sells swimwear and clothing, and began the business as a street vendor more than six years ago. Her greatest wish is to have her own store to give her customers better service. She requested the loan to buy towels, shorts, and tank tops. 

The group "Club De La Amistad" appreciates the Kiva investors for the loan provided. Liliana is the first person on the right in the back, wearing a black shirt.

loans.use: to buy towels, shorts, and tank tops.

loans.name: Isabel Reyna De Jesus

texts.es: Isabel tiene 66 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su hijo y su esposo. Isabel se dedica a la prestación de servicios domésticos desde hace mucho tiempo y es así como apoya en la economía de su familia. Isabel desea mejorar las condiciones de las paredes de la vivienda por lo que solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de cemento y arena para repellar todas las paredes de la vivienda y evitar que se deterioren.
texts.en: Isabel is 66 and lives in a house she owns with her son and husband.  She provides services as a domestic worker, has done this for a very long time and this is how she supports the economy of her family.  Isabel wants to improve the conditions of the walls in her house which is why she requests a loan to FUSAI to invest it in buying cement and sand to fix the walls of her house and avoid damage.

loans.use: to buy cement and sand to fix the walls of her house and avoid damage.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy jackets, shirts, trousers, shorts and other clothes to sell.

loans.name: Cleta

texts.en:
Cleta is married and works hard to support her family. She sells Avon products in the Philippines, which she has been doing for 11 years.

Cleta requested a loan from NWTF for 16,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional Avon products to sell to her customers. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional Avon products to sell

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia is 48 years old and is married with 4 children. With 3 children currently in school, Delia works very hard to provide for them.

Delia runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a 10,000 PHP loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation in order to buy additional items such as detergent soap, shampoo, soft drinks, coffee, noodles, etc. to sell in her store.

Delia has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items in her general store. 

In the future, Delia would like to save enough money to be able to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items like detergent soap, shampoo, soft drinks, coffee, noodles, etc. for resale.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira is 49 years old and married with two children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Elvira has a food-vending business in the Philippines. Elvira has requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase ingredients such as meat, fish, vegetables, spices, etc. for her food production business.

Elvira has been in this business for 10 years. Elvira would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients such as meat, fish, vegetables, spices, etc. for her food production business.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma is 31 years old, married, and has two children, one of whom attends school. She works very hard to provide for them. Emma operates a general store in the Philippines, which she has been doing for 10 years. She sells a variety of items such as shampoo, cooking oil, noodles, sugar, detergent soap, coffee, soft drinks, etc. 

Emma requested a loan from NWTF for 13,000 PHP, which she will use to to buy more stocks to sell to her customers. She would like to expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks to sell

loans.name: Rosaura

texts.es: Rosaura de 66 años de edad se dedica a la venta de ropa de manera ambulante por los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su lugar de residencia, ella vive en casa propia con sus dos hijos y sus dos nietos y esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas ropa por mayor para continuar con sus ventas y tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en: Rosaura is 66, she sells clothing around the different markets that are located close to her residence.  She lives in a house she owns with her two children and two grandchildren and she is requesting a loan to buy clothing at wholesale and continue with her sales and have more income.

loans.use: to buy clothing at wholesale prices.

loans.name: Maria Lucila

texts.es: Maria de 32 años de edad vive en propia con su esposo, ella se dedica a la venta de pescado desde hace varios años, comercializa de forma ambulante por los diferentes mercados, ella esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas pescados por mayor para poder continuar con sus ventas y así tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Maria is 32 years old and lives in her own home. For several years she has worked selling fish as a mobile vendor at various markets.

Maria is asking for a loan to buy more fish wholesale in order to continue with her sales and have a better income.

loans.use: buy more fish on the wholesale market.

loans.name: Wanda

texts.en:
Wanda is one of the most impressive people you will ever meet. She started the only African-American, woman-owned construction staffing agency in the United States, and she contracts workers to various large transportation projects in more than 25 different states.

She was working as a very successful loan processor in Orange County, when the real estate market crashed in 2008. She found herself needing a career change and wanted to relocate to San Diego.

It was then that she decided to start a staffing agency that helps construction workers find jobs. She overcame many challenges being a female in a male-dominated industry. Her entrepreneurial spirit helped her succeed in the construction industry, and her goals for the next few years include hiring more employees and staffing more large projects. She is very involved in the community, sitting on various boards and committees.

She has a passion for getting people back to work, and she pays all her workers a prevailing wage so that they can support their families.

Wanda needs a Kiva loan so that she can have working capital on hand so she can grow her business and win more construction projects to put more people back to work.

loans.use: to have working capital on hand so that she can grow her business and win more construction projects to put more people back to work.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma is a 43-year-old married woman with one child, who is still in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Elma has a business making direct-sales of Avon products. She has requested a loan of 12,000 PHP through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation in order to purchase more Avon products to sell.

Elma has been in this business for 17 years now. She would like to build and expand her business so she can secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more Avon products to sell.

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
Eufemia is 56 years old and a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Eufemia has a general store business in the Philippines. 

Eufemia requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

Eufemia has been in this business for 6 years. In the future, Eufemia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Fedila

texts.en:
Fedila works hard to support her family. Fedila is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Fedila requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

Fedila has been in this business for 10 years now.

Fedila would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Moises Antonio

texts.es: Moises vive en casa propia con su compañera de vida y su madre, el se dedica a la extracción de arena desde hace 10 años, ya tiene clientes establecidos donde comercializa la arena, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar los gastos de su casa, el esta solicitando un crédito para poder mejorar la carreta que muestra la fitografía ya que esa es su única fuente de trabajo y así poder tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Moises lives with his life companion and his mother in a house that he owns. He has earned his living extracting sand for ten years. He already has established customers to whom he sells the sand, and he is able to cover his household expenses with what he obtains from his sales. 

He is requesting a loan in order to improve the cart shown in the photograph. It is his only source of work, and the improvements will enable him to have a better income.

loans.use: to improve his work cart

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en:
Noeun, 46, lives in a small community of Battambang Province, Cambodia. He is a father of five single children. To make a living and support his family, he manages and operates a farming process, primarily growing rice and selling his agricultural product to the local dealers. On average, he is able to make an income of USD 5.00 a day.

Noeun wants to improve the general living conditions of the entire family by having a latrine to use, because there is no latrine in his house now. Therefore, he is borrowing a loan from Kiva to build a latrine. By doing this, he can help his family members gain access to sanitation, promote their health, and help to lessen environmental deterioration. He is thankful for the loan granted through HKL with a much lower interest rate than other general loan products.

loans.use: to build a latrine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, coffee, bread, milk, eggs, oil, toilet paper, etc. for his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more two bails of used clothing to  improve her business

loans.name: Ana Gloria

texts.es: Ana tiene 61 años de edad y habita en casa familiar junto a su esposo y sus hijos. Ana se dedica a la prestación de servicios domésticos lo cual le permite llevar el sustento a su hogar y dar a su familia mejores condiciones de vida. Ana desea cambiar el techo de su vivienda dado que con el tiempo se ha deteriorado y cuando es tiempo de lluvia el agua se filtra. Por lo anterior solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en a compra de lámina galvanizada, madera y polines para mejorar el techo de la vivienda.
texts.en:
Ana is 61 years old and lives in her family home with her husband and her children. She earns her living providing domestic services, which allow her to put food on the table and give her family better living conditions. Ana would like to replace the roof of her house since it has deteriorated with time and it leaks when the weather is rainy. 

For those reasons, she is requesting this loan from FUSAI in order to invest in the purchase of galvanized metal sheeting, wood, and roof beams in order to improve the roof of her house.

loans.use: to buy galvanized metal sheeting, wood, and roof beams to improve the roof of her house

loans.name: Veronica Guadalupe

texts.es:
Verónica, tiene un negocio en el que vende ropa, sandalias y chancletas; su vida la comparte con su esposo, cuatro hijos, su madre y dos hermanas, la casa en la que viven es alquilada; hizo la apertura del negocio hace 10 años, le pertenecía a su madre y Verónica le ayudaba a vender, posteriormente le compro el negocio y lo mantiene como fuente de ingresos familiar, su madre y una de sus hermanas le ayudan a atender a los clientes.
Invertirá un 50% en prendas de vestir, 30% en sandalias y chancletas, el resto que es un 20% lo utilizara para comprar maniquís, con la mercadería ofertara nuevos estilos de ropa y calzado, espera que sus ventas sean mayores, pues con la experiencia en el negocio identifica la época navideña como la indicada para las buenas ventas.
Sus proyectos son tener en el futuro un negocio más surtido, para aumentar la rentabilidad y cancelar sus deudas.
texts.en: Verónica has a business selling clothing, sandals, and flip-flops. He shares his life with his wife, 4 children, his mother, and two sisters. They live in a rented house. He opened his business 10 years ago. It belonged to her mother and Veronica used to help her sell. Later she bought the business and she now has the business as a source of income to support her family. Her mother and one of her sisters helps her attend to the customers. With regard to the loan, she will invest 50% in clothing items, 30% in sandals and flip-flops, and the remaining 20% to buy mannequins.  With the merchandise she will offer new styles of clothing and shoes. She hopes that her sales will increase, since experience indicates that the Christmas season brings good sales. Her future goals are to have a better stocked business, to increase her profits, and to pay her debts.

loans.use: to invest 50% in clothing items, 30% in sandals and flip-flops, and the remaining 20% to buy mannequins.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: This is 40 year-old Mary.  She is married and has two children ages 16 and 9 years old. She has one additional dependent who lives with her helping her with her school work.  In 2008, Mary established her Cosmetics business. She began her business just to be self-reliant after dropping out of school. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 500,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan of Le 3,000,000. Mary requires a loan in order to buy more eye pencils, face powder, lipsticks, beads and wrist watches for resale. In the future, Mary plans to expand her business to a shop, educate her children well and to be able to build a house.  She thanks you for your support

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics for her stall

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a single mother of three and the only provider for her family. She is a hardworking woman who loves to care for people, and is expanding her business into cleaning residential properties. She hopes to be able to clean offices in the near future.

Her passion is to care for the elderly, and she will continue to care for her current clients as she expands her offerings to cleaning. Currently, she provides care two to three days a week and cleans homes the other days.

One of her biggest challenges was last year when she lost a client because the client passed away. It took her a long time to find another client, so she wanted to expand her business into cleaning so that she would have another source income.

Maria says, “I love caring for people and providing for them, but I need another line of business to supplement my caretaker income. I've always liked taking care of people; I took care of my mother before she passed away. My challenges are that I do not have the equipment, insurance, and the professional cleaning tools and supplies I need.”

Maria will use her Kiva loan to buy a vacuum cleaner, cleaning products, and supplies such as sponges, mops, and brooms. She will also use the money to have business cards printed, as well as other marketing materials to spread the word about her cleaning and caretaking business.
